awd_titl_txt: CRISP Type 2: Interdependent Network-based Quantification of Infrastructure Resilience (INQUIRE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Critical infrastructure systems are increasingly reliant on one another for their efficient operation. This research will develop a quantitative, predictive theory of network resilience that takes into account the interactions between built infrastructure networks, and the humans and neighborhoods that use them. This framework has the potential to guide city officials, utility operators, and public agencies in developing new strategies for infrastructure management and urban planning.  More generally, these efforts will untangle the roles of network structure and network dynamics that enable interdependent systems to withstand, recover from, and adapt to perturbations. This research will be of interest to a variety of other fields, from ecology to cellular biology.


The project will begin by cataloging three built infrastructures and known interdependencies (both physical and functional) into a "network of networks" representation suitable for modeling. A key part of this research lies in also quantifying the interplay between built infrastructure and social systems. As such, the models will incorporate community-level behavioral effects through urban "ecometrics" -- survey-based empirical data that capture how citizens and neighborhoods utilize city services and respond during emergencies. This realistic accounting of infrastructure and its interdependencies will be complemented by realistic estimates of future hazards that it may face. The core of the research will use network-based analytical and computational approaches to identify reduced-dimensional representations of the (high-dimensional) dynamical state of interdependent infrastructure. Examining how these resilience metrics change under stress to networks at the component level (e.g. as induced by inundation following a hurricane) will allow identification of weak points in existing interdependent infrastructure. The converse scenario--in which deliberate alterations to a network might improve resilience or hasten recovery of already-failed systems--will also be explored.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Disclaimer

 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 

What were the major goals of the project?

 

The major goal was to focus on understanding the resilience of physical infrastructure systems, including aspects related to their interdependence with other systems, and changing dynamics due to perturbations. We aimed to make the concept of resilience predictable, quantifiable, and as a result, actionable. We did this by uncovering the key features of networks—both structural and dynamical—that underlie resilient interdependent critical infrastructure.

 

What key outcomes were achieved?

 

1.     Across all groups our research led to peer-reviewed books, journals, and conference publications. Together, we published XXX peer-reviewed publications in physics, computer science, and social science, among them many appearing in top venues, and such as Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Nature Physics, Science Advances, Nature Communications, SIGKDD, etc.

2.     Where relevant we published open-access codes and data, freely available for the research community. For example, our codes for analyzing recovery coupling during power grid failure and weather/environment change are published in GitHub, a free code-sharing hub.

3.     Our results were featured in several public outlets such as Phys.org (Reviving a failed network through microscopic interventions), Boston Globe (U.S. Cities segregated not just by where people live, but where they travel daily and A New Measure of Urban Racial Segregation), Harvard Gazette (New study measures neighborhood inequality and violence based on everyday mobility and To Advance Sustainability, Fight Inequality), Atlantic CityLab (The Segregation of Our Everyday Lives), etc.

 

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?

 

1.     The project provided sufficient professional development for junior researchers. For example, together we graduated more than five Ph.D. students and supported more than ten postdocs and graduate students.

2.     The project resulted two upper-level graduate courses (Time Series and Geospatial Data Sciences, Critical Infrastructure Resilience) and one upper-level undergraduate and entry-level graduate course (Climate Science, Engineering Adaptation, and Policy) at Northeastern University. 

 

How have the results been disseminated to communities of interest?

 

1.     Results from the project have been presented at academic conferences such as NetSciX 2020 (Waseda University, Tokyo, Japan), Networks 2021 (Indiana University Network Science Institute, USA), ACM SIGKDD Conference 2021 (Virtual Event, Singapore), etc.

2.     We co-chaired a workshop at ACM SIGKDD on sustainability and climate modelling.

3.     Two Ph.D. students contributed to the Climate Ready Greater Boston report (the GBRAG – Greater Boston Research Advisory Group report).

4.     One Ph.D. student collaborated with scientists at NASA Ames Research Center through NSF-INTERN grant (as part of NSF CRISP).

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2022
Modified by: Albert-Laszlo Barabasi
